Modification events related to critical.Data: Windows Event ID 5136; Windows Event ID 5137; Windows Event ID 5138; Windows Event ID 5139; Windows Event ID 5141
Modification events related to critical.Action: Monitor Windows Event IDs 5136, 5137, 5138, 5139, 5141 on Domain Controllers for changes to critical GPO objects (e.g., Default Domain Policy, Default Domain Controllers Policy). Identify changes affecting software installation, script execution, user rights assignment, or security options. Investigate changes originating from non-administrative accounts or service accounts.

Changes to domain trust relationships or.Data: Windows Event ID 307; Windows Event ID 510
Changes to domain trust relationships or.Action: Monitor relevant logs (Windows Event ID 307, 510) on ADFS/Identity Servers for modifications to domain trust settings, federation settings, or authentication methods (Managed to Federated). Identify changes originating from unusual accounts or locations. Use frequency analysis to identify rare configuration changes.

Modification of GPOs to enable remote co.Data: Windows Event ID 5136; Windows Event ID 5137; Windows Event ID 5138; Windows Event ID 5139; Windows Event ID 5141
Modification of GPOs to enable remote co.Action: Monitor Windows Event IDs 5136-5141 for changes to GPO settings related to 'Software Installation Policies', 'Startup/Shutdown Scripts', 'Scheduled Tasks', or 'User Rights Assignment' (specifically 'Act as part of the operating system', 'Create a token object', 'Enable trusted for delegation'). Correlate these policy changes with subsequent events indicating policy application on multiple endpoints or servers. Identify policy changes made by non-authorized accounts or occurring at unusual times.

Addition of new, unauthorized federated.Data: Windows Event ID 307; Windows Event ID 510
Addition of new, unauthorized federated.Action: Monitor relevant logs (Windows Event ID 307, 510) on Identity Servers for ActionTypes `Set federation settings on domain` or `Set domain authentication` that add new `AdditionalMfaRule` or modify existing `IssuanceTransformRules`, or add new Identity Providers. Use frequency analysis or baselining to detect these inherently rare events. Investigate source accounts and IPs for such changes.

Modification events for GPOs immediately.Data: Windows Event ID 5136; Windows Event ID 5137; Windows Event ID 5138; Windows Event ID 5139; Windows Event ID 5141; Windows Event ID 4688
Modification events for GPOs immediately.Action: Correlate GPO modification events (Windows Event ID 5136-5141) with subsequent process creation events (Windows Event ID 4688) on domain machines or servers, looking for suspicious executables or scripts launched shortly after a GPO update. Use time series analysis to identify unusual timing between policy changes and subsequent actions.

Rapid sequence of policy modification an.Data: Windows Event ID 5136; Windows Event ID 5137; Windows Event ID 5138; Windows Event ID 5139; Windows Event ID 5141; Windows Event ID 307; Windows Event ID 510
Rapid sequence of policy modification an.Action: Monitor sequence of policy modification (Windows Event ID 5136-5141) and deletion/undeletion/reversion events (Windows Event ID 5138, 5139, 5141, 307, 510) on Domain Controllers/Identity Servers. Identify rapid back-and-forth changes to the same policy objects. Analyze the time delta between modification and reversion using descriptive statistics (e.g., mean, min, max, stdev) to identify changes occurring much faster than normal administrative procedures.

Modification of GPOs or tenant policies.Data: Windows Event ID 5136; Windows Event ID 5137; Windows Event ID 5138; Windows Event ID 5139; Windows Event ID 5141
Modification of GPOs or tenant policies.Action: Monitor Windows Event IDs 5136-5141 for changes to GPO settings under 'Security Settings', 'Windows Firewall', 'Windows Defender', 'Audit Policy', or 'Software Restriction Policies'. Specifically look for configurations that disable services, exclude paths, or turn off auditing/logging. Use correlation analysis to link these policy changes with a subsequent decrease in security events or successful execution of previously blocked software on affected machines.

Modification of Active Directory configu.Data: Windows Event ID 5136; Windows Event ID 5137; Windows Event ID 5138; Windows Event ID 5139; Windows Event ID 5141
Modification of Active Directory configu.Action: Monitor Windows Event IDs 5136-5141 on Domain Controllers for the creation or modification of 'NTDSA' objects (representing domain controllers) or changes to Service Principal Names (SPNs) on critical service accounts or computers, which could indicate preparation for a rogue DC or authentication hijacking. Flag these highly sensitive object modifications for immediate investigation, especially if not part of a scheduled change process or originating from unauthorized accounts.
